revision.text:
The '''''Diccionario panhispánico de dudas''''' (Pan-Hispanic Dictionary of Doubts) or '''''DPD''''' is an elaborate work undertaken by the [[Real Academia Española]] (RAE – Royal Spanish Academy) and the [[Association of Spanish Language Academies]] with the goal of resolving questions related to the proper use of the [[Spanish language]]. Like other publications of the Academy, such as the ''[[Diccionario de la lengua española de la Real Academia Española]]'', the work follows a [[Linguistic prescription|linguistically prescriptive]] philosophy as opposed to a [[Linguistic description|descriptive]] one.<ref>Bonnin, Juan Eduardo. ''Decentralization of the linguistic norm online: the Royal Spanish Academy challenged on the Internet''. Tilburg University, Oct. 2012, p. 5.</ref> The first edition was published in 2005 and is now being revised to more properly align with principles set forth by the Academy's other publications.
The project was begun in response to the 50,000 questions received yearly by the constituent members of the Association of Spanish Language Academies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.consumer.es/web/es/educacion/2004/10/14/110278.php |title="Las 22 Academias de la Lengua Española aprueban el Diccionario Panhispánico de Dudas", EROSKI CONSUMER, 14 Oct. 2004 |publisher=Consumer.es |date=2004-10-14 |accessdate=2013-11-28}}</ref>
It is composed of:
* The [[dictionary]] itself * A set of five [[addendum|appendices]] covering [[grammatical conjugation|conjugation of verbs]], [[abbreviation]]s, symbols that can be ordered alphabetically, other symbols, and [[demonym]]s * A [[glossary]] of [[linguistics|linguistic terminology]] * A list of [[citation|works cited]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rae.es/recursos/diccionarios/dpd ''Diccionario panhispánico de dudas''] (1st edition, October 2005) at the RAE web site.
{{italic title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Diccionario panhispanico de dudas}} [[Category:Spanish dictionaries]] [[Category:2005 books]] {{spain-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = Global Arab Network (غلوبال اراب نتورك) |type = [[International organizations]], [[Business organizations]] |foundation = 2006 |location_city = [[London]] |location_country = [[UK]] |founder = |area_served = [[MENA]], Worldwide |key_people = [[Ghassan Ibrahim]](Editor in Chief) |industry = [[Business]] |num_employees = |homepage = [http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com www.globalarabnetwork.co.uk] }}
'''Global Arab Network''' (GAN) (in [[Arabic]]<ref>http://www.globalarabnetwork.com/ - [[الشبكة العربية العالمية]] [[غلوبال عرب نتوورك]] [[غلوبال عرب نتورك]] [[غلوبل اراب نتوورك]] [[غلوبل عرب نتوورك]] [[جلوبال عرب نتوورك]]</ref> غلوبال اراب نتورك) is a comprehensive news and information service about the Arab world in English and Arabic, registered and based in [[London]], [[Great Britain|UK]].
Founded in 2006, GAN covers news and information from the Middle East and North Africa concerning national and international affairs, relations between the Arab countries and the rest of the world, economy and business, foreign policy, science and technology, culture and society, entertainment and lifestyle. ".<ref>http://arab-niaba.org/english/links/bytopic.asp?tid=6 - United Nations Development Programme [[UNDP]]- POGAR Programme ]</ref>
Global Arab Network is one of the Strategic Partners of The Middle East Association<ref>http://www.the-mea.co.uk - [[The Middle East Association]]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com/ Global Arab Network (official homepage)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Global Arab Network}} [[Category:Arab media]] [[Category:Digital newspapers published in Europe]] [[Category:International business]] [[Category:Business organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:London newspapers]] [[Category:Publications established in 2006]] [[Category:Arabic-language newspapers]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} {|{{Infobox ship begin |display title=ICGV ''Ægir''}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Icelandic warship.jpg |Ship image size=300px |image alt= |Ship caption=Ægir }} {{Infobox ship career |Ship country=Iceland |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Iceland|naval}} |Ship name=''Ægir'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Aalborg Vaerft]], [[Denmark]] |Ship laid down=1967 |Ship launched=June 1968 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=1968 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship renamed= |Ship honours= |Ship status={{ship in active service}} |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship captured= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Ship class=[[Ægir-class offshore patrol vessel]] |Ship displacement={{convert|1128|LT|t|0}} |Ship length= {{convert|229|ft|1|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|33|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draught= {{convert|19|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship propulsion=*MAN 8L40/54 x 2 *2 × 3163 kW (4300 BHP) |Ship speed= {{convert|20|kn|mph km/h|lk=in}} |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship complement=16-19 |Ship capacity=64 |Ship sensors=*Surface Search: Sperry; E/F-band *Navigation: Furuno; I-band *Sonar: Hull-mounted high-frequency active search |Ship EW= |Ship armament=[[40 mm Bofors]] |Ship aircraft=One helicopter - [[Eurocopter AS332 Super Puma]] |Ship notes= }} |}
'''ICGV ''Ægir''''' is an [[OPV (naval)|Offshore Patrol vessel]] of the [[Icelandic Coast Guard]] built by Aalborg Værft, in [[Denmark]]. She is the first ship of the [[Ægir-class offshore patrol vessel|''Ægir'' class]] and is the sistership of the slightly improved [[ICGV Týr|ICGV ''Týr'']]. She participated in the two last [[Cod Wars]].
In 1990 the original [[QF 6 pounder Hotchkiss|57mm cannon]] was replaced with the current [[Bofors 40 mm|Bofors 40 mm gun]] and a large crane was added in 1994. The flight deck was enlarged in 1997 and in 2005 she was refitted in [[Poland]] with a new bridge and improved electronics suite.
== Historical ships == The first ship in the Icelandic Coast Guard to bear the name ''Ægir'' was commissioned on 14 July 1929. In her early years she was considered the most advanced patrol and inspection ship of the [[Nordic countries]]. She participated in the First [[Cod War]]. ''Ægir'' sailed with the newly elected president (1944) [[Sveinn Björnsson]] in the 1940s around Iceland. Full armament during the [[Second World War]] consisted of a [[QF 6 pounder Hotchkiss|57mm cannon]], 37mm [[anti-aircraft gun]], two [[machine gun]]s and [[depth charges]] along with various [[small arms]]. When the new ''Ægir'' arrived she was decommissioned and sold for scrap, even though she was still in excellent condition.
== External links == *http://www.lhg.is (in [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]]) *http://www.lhg.is/english/icg/about-us/ship/aegir/
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aegir}} [[Category:Ægir-class offshore patrol vessels]] [[Category:Ships built in Aalborg]] [[Category:1968 ships]] [[Category:Active patrol vessels of Iceland]]
{{Iceland-stub}}

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Macedonia]] (link changed to [[Republic of Macedonia]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox dance |title = Kopačka |image = |imagesize = |alt = |caption = |genre = [[Folk dance]] |signature = {{music|time|2|4}} |inventor = |year = |origin=[[Pijanec]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] }} '''Kopačka''' ({{lang-mk|Копачка}}; {{lang-en|The farmers dance}}) is a traditional [[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonian]] [[Hora (dance)|''Oro'']], folk dance, from the region of Pijanec, a range of mountains in the eastern part of the [[Republic of Macedonia]].
Kopačka is traditionally performed by male dancers. It is a fast-paced dance with fast movements on half feet, featuring extensive jumping, side movements and scissors movements. The dancers hold their belts with their left hand over the right one and begin their dance in a position of a half circle. The dance rhythm is {{music|time|2|4}}.
The dance was first introduced to [[Tanec]] (the national folklore performance group in the [[Republic of Macedonia]]) by the village dancers. The original name for the dance was Sitnata (Macedonian: Ситната; English: ''The small/fine one''). Tanec changed the name to Kopačka and the dance subsequently became so famous that the villagers adopted this name of Kopačka for both the dance and the name of their group, to remind everyone whence this dance originally came.
The dance is based on a combination of two songs: ''Dimna Juda'' for the slow, walking part of the dance, and ''Derviško Dušo (Viško)'' for the fast part of the dance.
==See also== *[[Kopanitsa]] *[[Kopačka (folklore ensemble)]] *[[Music of the Republic of Macedonia]]
==References== *Dimovski, Mihailo. (1977:80-6). ''Macedonian folk dances (Original in Macedonian: Македонски народни ора)''. Skopje: Naša kniga & Institut za folklor
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080331001314/http://www.dunav.org.il/dance_histories/macedonia_kopacka.html About the Kopačka dance] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t2_wrz7hBTs Video with a wedding lunch followed by the Kopačka dance on YouTube] * [http://www.vest.com.mk/default.asp?id=160043&idg=8&idb=2532&rubrika=Makedonija Kopačka folklore ensemble marks 60 years jubilee - Vest newspaper] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WvroIfN2jWQ Video of the Kopačka folk dance on YouTube] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7nqTaWRFkWA Video of the Kopačka folk dance by [[Tanec]] on YouTube]
{{Macedonian Oro}} {{Balkan music}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kopacka (folk dance)}} [[Category:Macedonian dances]]
{{macedonia-stub}} {{folk-dance-stub}}

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = State of Eritrea
Ministry of Foreign Affairs |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Emblem of Eritrea (or argent azur).svg |logo_width = 150px |logo_caption = [[Emblem of Eritrea]] |formed = |jurisdiction = [[Eritrea]] |headquarters = [[Asmara]] {{flagicon|Eritrea}} |coordinates = |chief1_name = [[Osman Saleh Mohammed]] |chief1_position = Minister |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = }} {{Politics of Eritrea}} The '''Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Eritrea''' is a government ministry which oversees the [[Foreign relations of Eritrea|foreign relations]] of [[Eritrea]]. Eritrea's current Minister of Foreign Affairs is [[Osman Saleh Mohammed]], since 2007.{{cite web|title=Eritrea - Heads of Government Listing|url=http://www.info.dfat.gov.au/info/hog/hog.nsf/ListSpecific?OpenForm&ExpandView&RestrictToCategory=Eritrea|publisher=Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|accessdate=20 November 2013}} ==List of ministers== This is a list of Ministers of Foreign Affairs of Eritrea:http://rulers.org/fm2.html *1993–1994: [[Mahmoud Ahmed Sherifo]] *1994–1997: [[Petros Solomon]] *1997–2000: [[Haile Woldense]] *2000–2005: [[Ali Said Abdella]] *2005–2007: [[Mohamed Omer (Eritrean politician)|Mohamed Omer]] (acting) *2007–present: [[Osman Saleh Mohammed]] ==See also== *[[Foreign aid to Eritrea]] *[[List of diplomatic missions of Eritrea]] *[[List of diplomatic missions in Eritrea]] {{Portal|Eritrea}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Eritrea-gov-stub}} [[Category:Government of Eritrea]]

[[User:Tom.Bot/Task3|Task 3]]: +{{Taxonbar|[[:Category:Taxonbar templates without from parameter|from]]=[[d:Special:EntityPage/Q2203804|Q2203804]]}} ([[WT:TREE#Taxonbar addition requirements|4 sig. taxon IDs]]); WP:GenFixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Speciesbox | image = Muggiaeaatlanticanectophor.jpg | taxon = Muggiaea atlantica | authority = Cunningham, 1892<ref name=WoRMS>{{cite WoRMS |author=Schuchert, Peter |year=2015 |title=''Muggiaea atlantica'' Cunningham, 1892 |id=135441 |accessdate=2015-04-14 }}</ref> }}
'''''Muggiaea atlantica''''' is a [[species]] of small [[hydrozoan]], a [[Siphonophorae|siphonophore]] in the [[Family (biology)|family]] [[Diphyidae]]. It is a cosmopolitan species occurring in inshore waters of many of the world's oceans, and it has colonised new areas such as the North Sea and the Adriatic Sea. It is subject to large population swings, and has been held responsible for the death of farmed salmon in Norway. The species was [[Species description|first described]] by J.T. Cunningham in 1892 from a specimen obtained at [[Plymouth]], England.
==Description== ''Muggiaea atlantica'' is a small colonial [[siphonophore]], but one of the two nectophores (swimming bells) is undeveloped. The remaining nectophore grows to a length of about {{convert|7|mm|1|abbr=on}}. It is translucent and has five straight, longitudinal ridges, some of which may form a keel. The hydroecium (ventral cavity) is about one third of the length of the nectophore, and the long slender somatocyst (extension of the gastrovascular system) reaches the apex of the nectosac (central cavity) and sometimes contains oil droplets.<ref name=MSIP>{{cite web |url=http://species-identification.org/species.php?species_group=zmns&id=139 |title=''Muggiaea atlantica'' |author=van Couwelaar, M. |work=Zooplankton and Micronekton of the North Sea |publisher=Marine Species Identification Portal |accessdate=2015-04-14}}</ref><ref name=Todd>{{cite book|author1=C. D. Todd|author2=M. S. Laverack|author3=Geoff Boxshall|title=Coastal Marine Zooplankton: A Practical Manual for Students |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9KCRsSQQ-uwC&pg=PT19|year=1996 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-55533-3|page=19}}</ref> The eudoxid (reproductive stage) soon becomes detached. It has a cone-shaped, asymmetric bract with a wide flanged suture running from apex to base. The right edge of the bract is curved while the left edge is truncated horizontally. The lower surface has a small cavity in which the somatocyst is situated.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Russell, F.S. |authorlink = Frederick Stratten Russell|year=1938 |title=On the Development of ''Muggiaea atlantica'' Cunningham |journal=Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=441–446 |doi=10.1017/S0025315400012340 }}</ref>
==Distribution and habitat== ''Muggiaea atlantica'' is a [[Neritic zone|neritic]] species that forms part of the [[zooplankton]], and is found in the upper hundred metres of inshore temperate and subtropical waters worldwide. It is present in the Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean. It is a common siphonophore and probably more abundant than any other species of siphonophore in nearshore habitats. Its abundance is seasonal, and in parts of the northern hemisphere it has population peaks in May/June and again in September/November.<ref name=Mapstone>{{cite book|author1=Mapstone, Gillian M.|author2=Arai, Mary N.|title=Siphonophora (Cnidaria: Hydrozoa) of Canadian Pacific Waters |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8epLkhYnBGYC&pg=PA23 |year=2009 |publisher=NRC Research Press |isbn=978-0-660-19843-9|pages=23–33}}</ref> In the western English Channel it occurred sporadically before the 1960s but after 1968 it became resident. Its seasonal distribution and abundance seem to be associated with sea temperature changes and the availability of food.<ref name=Blackett>{{cite journal |author1=Blackett, Michael |author2=Licandro, Priscilla |author3=Coombs, Steve H. |author4=Lucas, Cathy H. |year=2014 |title=Long-term variability of the siphonophores ''Muggiaea atlantica'' and ''M. kochi'' in the Western English Channel |journal=Progress in Oceanography |volume=128 |pages=1–14 |doi=10.1016/j.pocean.2014.07.004 }}</ref> It appeared in the southern [[Adriatic Sea]] for the first time in the mid 1990s and became increasingly common there. It was detected in the marine lakes on the island of [[Mljet]] in southern Croatia in 2001, and seems to have displaced ''[[Muggiaea kochii]]'' in the Great Lake there. It is hypothesized that the cold winter of 2000/2001 favoured the more cold-tolerant ''M. atlantica'' over the warm-temperate ''M. kochii''.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Batistić, Mirna |author2=Lučić, Davor |author3=Carić, Marina |author4=Garić, Rade |author5=Licandro, Priscilla |author6=Jasprica, Nenad |year=2013 |title=Did the alien calycophoran ''Muggiaea atlantica'' outcompete its native congeneric ''M. kochi'' in the marine lakes of Mljet Island (Croatia)? |journal=Marine Ecology |volume=34 |issue=s1 |pages=3–13 |doi=10.1111/maec.12021 }}</ref>
==Ecology== ''Muggiaea atlantica'' swims in an arc, propelled by pulsations of its bell, and then remains stationary for several minutes.<ref name=Pitt/> It feeds almost entirely on [[copepod]]s, consuming an estimated five to ten prey items daily, mostly during the night.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Purcell, Jennifer E. |year=1982 |title=Feeding and growth of the siphonophore ''Muggiaea atlantica'' (Cunningham 1893) |journal=Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology |volume=62 |issue=1 |pages=39–54 |doi=10.1016/0022-0981(82)90215-5}}</ref> In the eastern Pacific it is eaten by [[Predation|predatory]] fish such as the [[blue rockfish]] (''Sebastes mystinus''), and by the floating sea snail ''[[Carinaria cristata]]''.<ref name=Mapstone/>
Reproduction in this species is by an alternation of generations between an asexual polygastric animal (bearing both asexual and reproductive elements) and the sexual eudoxid stage which becomes detached from the nectophore. The generation time is short and under favourable conditions, numbers can build up rapidly.<ref name=Blackett/>
A population explosion of ''M. atlantica'' in the North Sea in 1989 caused major changes in the composition of the community. The siphonophere was present at densities of five hundred per cubic metre and this depleted the copepods normally present. This resulted in a reduction in the grazing pressure on the phytoplankton and an increase in their growth, causing an [[algal bloom]] and other cascading [[ecosystem]] effects.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Greve, Wulf |year=1994 |title=The 1989 German Bight invasion of ''Muggiaea atlantica'' |journal=ICES Journal of Marine Science |volume=51 |issue=4 |pages=355–358 |doi=10.1006/jmsc.1994.1037 }}</ref>
The [[aquaculture]] industry in Norway suffered a setback in 2007 when more than 100,000 caged [[salmon]] were killed by a bloom of ''M. atlantica'', present at a concentration of 2,000 per cubic metre in coastal waters.<ref name=Pitt>{{cite book|author1=Pitt, Kylie A. |author2=Lucas, Cathy H. |title=Jellyfish Blooms |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zr_EBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA133 |year=2013 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=978-94-007-7015-7 |pages=121–134}}</ref> This siphonophore is also thought to have been involved in the loss of a million farmed salmon in Ireland in 2003.<ref>{{cite book|author1= Woo, Patrick T. K.|author2=Gregory, David W. Bruno |title=Diseases and Disorders of Finfish in Cage Culture, 2nd Edition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8caWBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA120|year=2014 |publisher=CABI |isbn=978-1-78064-207-9 |page=120}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Taxonbar|from=Q2203804}}
[[Category:Siphonophorae]] [[Category:Animals described in 1892]] [[Category:Cosmopolitan animals]]

{{Infobox station | name = Ngaoundéré Central Station | native_name = Gare centrale de Ngaoundéré | native_name_lang = fr | symbol_location = | symbol = | type = | image = Stazione di Ngaoundéré.jpg | alt = | caption = The station in 2010 | address = | borough = | country = | coordinates = {{coord|7.3385|13.5898|type:railwaystation_region:CM|display=inline,title}} | owned = | operator = [[Camrail]] | line = Yaoundé-Bélabo-Ngaoundéré line | distance = | platforms = | tracks = | train_operators = | connections = | structure = | parking = | bicycle = | disabled = | code = | zone = | website = | opened = {{Start date|1974|12|10}} | closed = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | passengers = | pass_year = | pass_rank = | services = }} The '''Ngaoundéré Central Station''' (''Gare centrale de Ngaoundéré'' in French) is the main [[railway station]] in [[Ngaoundéré]], [[Cameroon]]. It is located on the Yaoundé-Bélabo-Ngaoundéré line of the [[Camrail]] network.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.camrail.net/reseau.html|title=Réseau |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2014| website=Camrail.net| language=French |publisher=CAMRAIL|accessdate=May 24, 2014}}</ref>
The station was opened on December 10, 1974. It was extensively renovated in 2012, at a cost of around two billion [[CFA francs]]. This renovation added 22 benches, 16 lamps, toilet blocks, commercial buildings, the installation of tiles and the construction of offices for the Commissioner of Railways.<ref>{{cite news |last=Petsoko |first=Mathurin |date=June 15, 2012 |title=Gare voyageurs relookée de Ngaoundéré: Les nouvelles installations inaugurées |trans-title=Passenger station revamped in Ngaoundere: New facilities inaugurated |url=http://www.journalducameroun.com/article.php?aid=11545 |language=French |newspaper=Journal du Cameroun |location= |publisher=Journal du Cameroun| accessdate=May 24, 2014 }}</ref>
The station serves as a discharge point for fresh foods which are then loaded into trucks for transport to points in the north of the country and in [[Chad]]. While a true dry port, the railway station in Ngaoundere lacks the appropriate infrastructure for the storage of fresh food. The food items are left in the open air, close to other types of goods, regardless of the type.<ref>{{cite conference |url=http://hal.cirad.fr/cirad-00471165 |title=Filières fruitières dans les savanes du Cameroun et du Tchad |last1=DANDJOUMA |first1= A.|date= April 20–23, 2009|booktitle=Actes du colloque «Savanes africaines en développement: innover pour durer» |page= 7|language= French|display-authors=et. al.}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Rail transport in Cameroon]] * [[Railway stations in Cameroon]] * [[Transport in Cameroon]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ngaoundere Central Station}} [[Category:Railway stations in Cameroon]] [[Category:Railway stations opened in 1974]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Cameroon]] [[Category:Adamawa Region]]
{{Cameroon-stub}} {{Africa-rail-transport-stub}}

{{Infobox airport | name = Rafaï Airport | IATA = RFA | ICAO = FEGR | type = Public | city-served = [[Rafaï]] | location = | owner = Government | elevation-f = 1759 | elevation-m = | coordinates = {{coord|4|59|20|N|23|55|41|E|region:CF_type:airport|name=Rafaï Airport (Rafaï)|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Central African Republic | pushpin_label = '''RFA''' | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Rafaï Airport in the
Central African Republic | metric-rwy = y | r1-number = 01/19 | r1-length-f = | r1-length-m = 1260 | r1-surface = Grass | footnotes = Source: Landings.com[http://aerobaticsweb.org/cgi-bin/search_apt?FEGR Airport record for Rafaï Airport] at Landings.com. Retrieved 2013-08-26 Google maps{{Google maps|url=https://maps.google.com/maps?ht=en&z=13&t=k&q=4.98863888888889,23.9280833333333+%28Rafaï+Airport%29|title=location of Rafaï Airport|accessdate=2013-08-26}} GCM{{GCM|FEGR|Rafaï Airport}} }} '''Rafaï Airport''' {{Airport codes|RFA|FEGR}} is an [[airstrip]] serving [[Rafaï]], a village in the [[Mbomou]] prefecture of the [[Central African Republic]]. Rafaï village lines the RN2 road, and the runway is located mid-village just off the road. ==See also== *{{portal-inline|Central African Republic}} *{{portal-inline|Aviation}} *[[Transport in the Central African Republic]] *[[List of airports in the Central African Republic]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=13/4.9848/23.9293 OpenStreetMap - Rafaï] *[http://ourairports.com/airports/FEGR/ OurAirports - Rafaï Airport] *{{ASN|RFA|Rafaï Airport}} {{Airports in the Central African Republic}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rafai Airport}} [[Category:Airports in the Central African Republic]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Mbomou]] {{CentralAfricanRepublic-airport-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Rolls of Oléron''' (''Rôles d'Oléron'', also known as the "Judgments of Oleron" and the "Rules of Oléron") were the first formal statement of [[Admiralty law|"maritime" or "admiralty" laws]] in northwestern [[Europe]].
They were promulgated by [[Eleanor of Aquitaine]] in about 1160, after her return from the [[second crusade]] having accompanied her first husband [[Louis VII of France|Louis VII]]. They were based upon the ancient ''[[Lex Rhodia]]'', which had governed Mediterranean commerce since before the 1st century. She likely became acquainted with them while at the court of King [[Baldwin III of Jerusalem]], who had adopted them, as the ''Maritime Assizes of the Kingdom of Jerusalem''. They are named for the island of [[Oléron]] since the island was the site of the maritime court associated with the most powerful seamen's guild of the Atlantic. She promulgated them in [[England]] at the very end of the twelfth century having been granted viceregal powers of England while King [[Richard I]] was on the [[third crusade]].<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Livingstone | last = Keevil | first = John Joyce | title = Medicine and the Navy,1200-1900,vol.1: 1200-1649 | year = 1957 }}</ref>
They were published subsequently in [[France|French]] and English. The English King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] published them as "The judgment of the sea, of Masters, of Mariners, and Merchants, and all their doings." The Rolls greatly influenced the Baltic [[Laws of Wisbuy]] and are included in the English "[[Black Book of the Admiralty]]". They may also have influenced later maritime codes such the various "[[Pirate code|Articles]]" enforced by some [[Golden Age of Piracy|Golden Age]] pirates, for example, the "Obligations" of [[George Cusack]], who referred to them as the "Lawes of Pleron".<ref name="Fox Dissertation">{{cite book|last1=Fox|first1=E. T.|title=‘Piratical Schemes and Contracts’: Pirate Articles and their Society, 1660-1730|date=2013|publisher=University of Exeter|location=Exeter|url=https://ore.exeter.ac.uk/repository/bitstream/handle/10871/14872/FoxE.pdf|accessdate=15 June 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [[Erastus C. Benedict|Benedict EC]], Jhirad EE, Knauth AW and Knauth CR (1973) [https://books.google.com/books?id=6kM3AQAAIAAJ&q=%22Benedict+on+Admiralty%22+%22volume+1%22&dq=%22Benedict+on+Admiralty%22+%22volume+1%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=GEzyU8XYMZDwoATduID4Bg&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA ''Benedict on Admiralty''] Volume 1, Ch II, § 26. M. Bender.
==External links== Full text: [http://www.admiraltylawguide.com/documents/oleron.html The Rules of Oléron ~1266]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rolls Of Oleron}} [[Category:Admiralty law]] [[Category:12th century in law]] [[Category:Oléron]]
{{Europe-law-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Diocese <!-- Type of jurisdiction: i.e. Diocese or Archdiocese --> | name = Lokoja <!-- Place name(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | latin = Dioecesis Lokoianus<!-- Latin name of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | local = <!-- Name in the native language --> | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = <!---- Locations ----> | country = {{flag|Nigeria}} | territory = [[Kogi State]] | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Abuja|Abuja]]<!-- Ecclesiastical province --> | metropolitan = Cardinal of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Abuja|Abuja]] | archdeaconries = | deaneries = | subdivisions = | coordinates = {{coord|7|48|08|N|6|44|34|E|}}<!-- Use {{coord}} --> <!---- Statistics ----> | area_km2 = 24,750 <!-- Area in square kilometers, automatically converted --> | area_sqmi = <!-- Area in square miles, automatically converted --> | area_footnotes = | population = 1,465,530 | population_as_of = 2004 | catholics = 36,507<!-- Number of Catholics in the diocese --> | catholics_percent = 2.5 | parishes = <!-- Number of parishes in the diocese --> | churches = <!-- Number of churches in the diocese --> | congregations = <!-- Number of congregations in the diocese --> | schools = <!-- Number of church supported schools in the diocese --> | members = <!-- Number of members in the diocese --> <!---- Information ----> | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | rite = [[Latin Rite]] <!-- e.g., [[Latin Rite]] --> | established = July 6, 1964 | cathedral = Immaculate Conception Cathedral in [[Lokoja]]<!-- Cathedral that serves as the seat of the diocese --> | cocathedral = | patron = <!-- Patron saint(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | patron_title = <!-- Use to override the default label "Patron saint" --> | priests = <!-- Number of priests in the diocese --> <!---- Current leadership ----> | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} <!-- DO NOT CHANGE. This will update the Popes Automatically as they change --> | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = Most Rev. [[Martin Dada Abejide Olorunmolu]]<!-- Name and title of the current ordinary of the diocese --> | bishop_title = <!-- Type of ordinary: i.e. Bishop or Archbishop. Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = <!-- Name of the Metropolitan Archbishop of the Ecclesiastical Province --> | coadjutor = | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> <!---- Map ----> | map = Nigeria Kogi State map.png | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = Lokoja is located in [[Kogi State]] which is shown here in red. <!---- Website ----> | website = http://catholicdioceseoflokoja.org.ng | footnotes = }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Lokoja''' ({{lang-la|Lokoian(us)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Lokoja]], [[Kogi State]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Abuja|Abuja]] in [[Nigeria]].
==History== * February 21, 1955: Established as Apostolic Prefecture of Kabba from the [[Diocese of Benin City]], [[Diocese of Kaduna]] and [[Apostolic Prefecture of Oturkpo]] * July 6, 1964: Promoted as Diocese of Kabba * May 5, 1965: Renamed as Diocese of Lokoja
AN OUTLINE OF A HISTORY OF THE CATHOLIC DIOCESE OF LOKOJA
While the advent of the Catholic Faith in the Catholic Diocese of Lokoja is usually dated to the opening of a new mission in Lokoja in 1884, the birth of the Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction, which we now call Lokoja Diocese must be dated back to 1955, when Kabba Prefecture was created, and later became Lokoja Diocese.
The creation of Kabba Prefecture resulted from a lengthy correspondence between the then Provincial and Superior-General of French-Canadian Spiritans (Canadian Spiritans). For at the end of the First World War German Missionaries were forced to leave the Cameroon, and the members of the French-Canadian Province of the Spiritans were asked to take over the German Mission in the Cameroon. Thus, the Cameroon became the field of work for the Canadian Spiritans until 1947 when their mission activity was shifted to Nigeria; in Nigeria they teamed up with their confreres from England under the authority of Father Francis Murray, the Administrator of the Prefecture of Benue until the arrival of Msgr. James Hagan as Prefect Apostolic.
In March 1955 the Prefecture of Kabba was created from Benin City Diocese and the Prefecture of Otukpo by the Vatican decree Number 1017 dated March 01, 1955; and Msgr Auguste Delisle, CSSp, a missionary since 1935 and on the Nigerian team since 1952 became the Prefect Apostolic by the Vatican decree number 2579 dated May 27, 1955. The new Prefecture was a suffragan of the Archdiocese of Onitsha. In terms of political pision Kabba Prefecture was coterminous with Kabba Province.
It was not until 1964 that the Prefecture of Kabba was raise to status of a Diocese by a Vatican decree dated July 06, 1964 with Msgr. A. Delisle as its first bishop; the name of the new diocese was Kabba and it remained a suffragan of Onitsha Archdiocese until ten weeks later when by a Vatican decree dated September 14, 1964 the Diocese of Kabba was made a suffragan of Kaduna. And by ye another Vatican decree number 1734 dated May 05, 1965 the Diocese of Kabba changed name to Diocese of Lokoja. According to Bishop Makozi,
The Prefecture of Kabba changed name briefly to Diocese of Kabba. To facilitate the administration of the diocese, the name was changed, of course with the approval of Rome, to Diocese of Lokoja, since the Kabba Provincial Headquarters was Lokoja where the Provincial Resident and his political administration resided.
A major pastoral progress was made when Idah Prefecture was created out of Lokoja Diocese with Msgr. Leopold Grimard as the Prefect Apostolic; the Prefecture was raised to the status of a diocese in 1978 with Bishop Ephraim S. Obot as its first bishop.
In 1971 the slow but sure process of indigenization of Kabba ecclesiastical jurisdiction that started with the priestly ordination of the duo of Alexius O. Makozi and Joseph Ohieku, assumed a far-reaching development when on May 30,1971 was raised to the episcopate as auxiliary bishop of Lokoja; Bishop Makozi became the bishop of Lokoja in 1972. Thus Bishop A. Delisle was the local ordinary of Kabba\Lokoja ecclesiastical jurisdiction for about seventeen years (1955 – 1972).
Bishop A.O. Makozi administered the diocese of Lokoja as the local ordinary until 1992 when he was transferred to the diocese of Port Harcourt. Bishop Joseph Sunday Ajomo replaced Bishop Makozi on May 03, 1992 as the bishop of Lokoja until he joined the Church Triumphant on June 20, 2004. May he rest in peace.
Following the sudden death of Bishop Joseph Sunday Ajomo, Late Very Rev. Fr. Joseph Ohieku was appointed the Diocesan Administrator in accordance with the relevant canonical provisions. He was automatically relieved when the Bishop elect, Msgr. Martin Dada Abejide Olorunmolu (appointed November 11, 2005), was ordained and installed February 11, 2006 as the fourth bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Lokoja. (See http://catholicdioceseoflokoja.org.ng/history-of-lokoja-diocese/)
==Special churches== The [[Cathedral]] is Immaculate Conception Cathedral in Lokoja.
==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Lokoja (Roman rite) ** Bishop Martin Dada Abejide Olorunmolu (since 2005.11.11) ** Bishop [[Joseph Sunday Ajomo]] (1992.03.06 – 2004.06.21) ** Bishop [[Alexius Obabu Makozi]] (1972.07.30 – 1991.08.31) ** Bishop [[Auguste Delisle]], [[C.S.Sp.]] (1965.05.05 – 1972.07.30) * Bishops of Kabba (Roman rite) ** Bishop Auguste Delisle, C.S.Sp. (1964.07.06 – 1965.05.05) * Prefects Apostolic of Kabba (Roman rite) ** Bishop Auguste Delisle, C.S.Sp. (1955.05.27 – 1964.07.06)
==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Nigeria]]
==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/loko0.htm GCatholic.org Information] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dlkja.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://catholicdioceseoflokoja.org.ng/]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lokoja}} [[Category:Catholic Church in Nigeria]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Nigeria]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1955]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]] [[Category:1955 establishments in Nigeria]]
{{Nigeria-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Solsona |latin = Dioecesis Celsonensis |local = Diócesis de Solsona ''Spanish''
Diòcesi de Solsona ''Catalan'' |image = Catedral i portal del Pont a Solsona.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = [[Solsona Cathedral]] |country = [[Spain]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Tarragona|Tarragona]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Tarragona|Tarragona]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |established = 19 July 1593 |cathedral = [[Solsona Cathedral|Cathedral of St Mary in Solsona]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 3,536 |population = 139,900 |population_as_of = 2010 |catholics = 128,700 |catholics_percent= 92 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Xavier Novell Goma]] |coadjutor = |metro_archbishop = |auxiliary_bishops= |emeritus_bishops = Jaume Traserra Cunillera Bishop Emeritus (2001-2010) |map = [http://www.bisbatsolsona.cat/ Website of the Diocese] |website = }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Solsona''' ({{lang-la|Celsonen(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Solsona, Lleida|Solsona]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Tarragona|Tarragona]] in Spain.[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dsols.html "Diocese of Solsona"] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved February 29, 2016[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/sols0.htm "Diocese of Solsona"] ''GCatholic.org''. Gabriel Chow. Retrieved February 29, 2016 ==History== * 19 July, 1593: Established as Diocese of Solsona from the [[Diocese of Urgell]] and [[Diocese of Vic]] ==Ordinaries== *Luis Sans y Códol (3 Oct 1594 – 20 Aug 1612 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Barcelona|Bishop of Barcelona]]) *Juan Alvarez Zapata, [[O. Cist.]] (11 Mar 1613 – 13 Oct 1623 Died) *Miguel Santos de Sampedro (15 Apr 1624 – 13 Nov 1630 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Granada|Archbishop of Granada]]) *Pedro Puigmartí Funes, [[order of Saint Benedict|O.S.B.]] (16 Dec 1630 – Nov 1632 Died) *[[Diego Serrano Sotomayor]], [[O. de M.]] (3 Dec 1635 – 30 May 1639 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Segorbe|Bishop of Segorbe]]) *Pedro (de Santiago) Anglada Sánchez, [[Order of Augustinian Recollects|O.A.R.]] (30 Jan 1640 – 14 Nov 1644 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Lleida|Bishop of Lerida]]) *Francisco Roger, [[Order of Preachers|O.P.]] (18 Sep 1656 – 18 Jan 1663 Died) *Luis de Pons y de Esquerrer, [[Order of Saint Benedict]] (11 Aug 1664 – 4 Jan 1685 Died) *Manuel de Alba (10 Sep 1685 – 24 Aug 1693 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Barcelona|Bishop of Barcelona]]) *[[Juan Alfonso Valerià y Aloza]], [[Order of Friars Minor|O.F.M.]] (8 Feb 1694 – 1 Jun 1699 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Lleida|Bishop of Lerida]]) *Guillermo Goñalons, [[Order of Saint Augustine|O.S.A.]] (30 Mar 1700 – 12 Aug 1708 Died) *Francisco Dorda, [[O. Cist.]] (19 Feb 1710 – 3 Dec 1716 Died) *Pedro Magaña, [[Order of Saint Benedict|O.S.B.]] (10 May 1717 – 9 Feb 1718 Died) *Tomás Broto y Pérez (27 May 1720 – 8 Apr 1736 Died) *José Esteban Noriega, [[O. Praem.]] (27 Jan 1738 – 10 May 1739 Died) *Francisco Zarceño Martínez, [[O.SS.T.]] (14 Dec 1739 – 23 Jan 1746 Died) *José Mezquía Díaz de Arrízola, [[O. de M.]] (16 Sep 1746 – 9 Sep 1772 Died) *Rafael Lasala y Locela, [[Order of Saint Augustine|O.S.A.]] (15 Mar 1773 – 17 Jun 1792 Died) [[Rafael Lazcano]], ''Episcopologio agustiniano''. Agustiniana, Guadarrama (Madrid) 2014, vol. I, p. 403-412. *Agustín Vázquez Varela, [[O. Cist.]] (17 Jun 1793 – 11 Feb 1794 Died) *Pedro Nolasco Mora Mora, [[O. de M.]] (12 Sep 1794 – 1 Mar 1811 Died) *Manuel Benito y Tabernero (19 Dec 1814 – 25 Jul 1830 Died) *Juan José Tejada Sáenz, [[O. de M.]] (2 Jul 1832 – 15 Jun 1838 Died) *Valentín Comellas y Santamaría (18 Dec 1919 – 19 Mar 1945 Died) *[[Vicente Enrique y Tarancón]] (25 Nov 1945 – 12 Apr 1964 Appointed, [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Oviedo|Archbishop of Oviedo]]) *José Bascuñana y López (20 May 1964 – 19 Feb 1977 Resigned) *Miguel Moncadas Noguera (1 Apr 1977 – 5 Aug 1989 Died) *Antonio Deig Clotet (7 Mar 1990 – 28 Jul 2001 Retired) *Jaume Traserra Cunillera (28 Jul 2001 – 3 Nov 2010 Retired) *Xavier Novell Gomá (3 Nov 2010 – ) ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Spain]] == References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dsols.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.bisbatsolsona.cat/ Diocese website] * {{CathEncy|wstitle=Solsona}} {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain}} {{coord|41|58|47|N|1|30|47|E|source:cawiki_region:ES-CT_type:adm2nd|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solsona}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Catalonia]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1593]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses established in the 16th century]] {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Sukkites''' were an ancient [[Africa]]n nation. It is mentioned in the [[Hebrew Bible]] as one of three that followed King [[Shishaq]] (also spelled "Shishak," and associated by many scholars with [[Shoshenq I]]) of [[Egypt]] in his invasion of [[Jerusalem]]. This is the only biblical reference to Sukkiim.
[[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]] 2, Chapter 12:
:''And it came to pass, when [[Rehoboam]] had established the [[Kingdom of Judah|kingdom]], and had strengthened himself, he forsook the law of the Lord, and all [[Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)|Israel]] with him...And it came to pass, that in the fifth year of king Rehoboam Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem, because they had transgressed against the Lord. With twelve hundred [[chariot]]s, and threescore thousand horsemen: and the people were without number that came with him out of Egypt; the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians.''
==See also== *[[History of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Hebrew Bible nations]] [[Category:History of Africa]]
{{Tanakh-stub}}

page.title: The Day the Leader was Killed

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight|auto=all | name = USA-262 | image = Navstar-2F.jpg | image_caption = A Block IIF GPS satellite | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 2015-033A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=2015-033A|title=Navstar 74|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=15 July 2015}} | SATCAT = 40730 | mission_duration = 12 years (planned) | spacecraft = GPS SVN-72 (IIF-10) | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIF]] | manufacturer = [[Boeing]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1630|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|15 July 2015, 15:36|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Atlas V]] 401,}} AV-055 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41|SLC-41]] | launch_contractor = [[United Launch Alliance|ULA]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = 15 July 2015, 21:23:20 UTC | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20450|km|abbr=on}} | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20445|km|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 55.00 degrees | orbit_period = 728.77 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-262''', also known as '''GPS IIF-10''', '''GPS SVN-72''' and '''NAVSTAR 74''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the tenth of twelve [[GPS Block IIF|Block IIF]] satellites to be launched. == Launch == Built by [[Boeing]] and launched by [[United Launch Alliance]], USA-262 was launched at 15:36 UTC on 15 July 2015, atop a [[Atlas V]] 401 carrier rocket, vehicle number AV-055.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=15 July 2015}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41|Space Launch Complex 41]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=15 July 2015}} and placed USA-262 directly into [[semi-synchronous orbit]]. == Orbit == As of 15 July 2015, USA-262 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20445|km|sp=us}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20450|km|sp=us}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 728.77 minutes, and 55.00 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=15 July 2015}} It is used to broadcast the PRN 08 signal, and operates in slot 3 of plane C of the GPS constellation. The satellite has a design life of 15 years and a mass of {{convert|1630|kg}}. {{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2f.htm|title=GPS-2F (Navstar-2F)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=15 July 2015}} It is currently in service following commissioning on August 12, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.navcen.uscg.gov/?Do=gpsShowNanu&num=2015073|title=NOTICE ADVISORY TO NAVSTAR USERS (NANU) 2015073|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|accessdate=13 December 2014}} {{-}} == References == {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{reflist}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 2015}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2015]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Atlas rockets]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

[[Image:Wdx logo.jpg|thumb|alt=symbol of the Wocu.|The logo of the WDX Institute.]] The '''WDX Institute''' is a not-for-profit research body established to further academic research on World Currency Baskets. It is responsible for independently monitoring the Algorithm of the [[Wocu]], a standardized basket of currencies comprising the national currencies of the 20 largest national economies measured by [[GDP]].
==See also== *[[Wocu]] *[[Special drawing rights]] *[[Bancor]] *[[European Currency Unit]] *[[World currency unit]] *[[World currency]]
==References==
* Coats, Warren (1989) "In Search of a Monetary Anchor : A 'New' Monetary Standard," IMF Working Paper No. 89/82. * Staff of the International Monetary Fund (2009) "[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2009/02/pdf/text.pdf World Economic Outlook, October 2009: Sustaining the Recovery]", October 15, 2009 * Kang, Shi, Juanyi Xu (2008) "The Optimal Currency Basket with Input Currency and Output Currency," HKIMR Working Paper No. 17/2008
== External links == *[http://www.wdxinstitute.org/wdx/ WDX Institute] *[http://www.wocu.com Wocu]
[[Category:International economic organizations]] [[Category:Research institutes in London]]
